newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Senate set to vote on lender liability relief.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Senate set to vote on lender liability relief.

text.p: The U.S. Senate is expected to vote on Monday on a measure to relieve lenders of any liability for cleaning up toxic waste on properties they have had to take over because of loan defaults.

The provision was included in a catch-all spending bill, which the House passed Saturday and which was expected to go to the White House later Monday in time for the start of the new fiscal year on Oct 1.
Lawmakers agreed on the uncontroversial change to the Superfund toxic waste cleanup law in a compromise with bankers to bolster the Savings Association Insurance Fund.
The lender liability relief was the only Superfund reform backed by Congress after more than a year of haggling over proposals to overhaul the multibillion dollar hazardous waste cleanup program.
Insurance groups were disappointed that the narrow banking provision was detached from the broader Superfund debate, because it would diffuse bankers' interest in broader reform.
"We prefer to keep a tight coalition on Superfund reform," said American Insurance Association spokesman Dan Zielinski.
